position.title: Catedrático de Universidad (Full Professor)
position.summary:
Antonio Fernández-Caballero received his Master in Computer Science from the School of Computer Science at the Technical University of Madrid, Spain, and he received his Ph.D. from the Department of Artificial Intelligence of the National University for Distance Education, Spain.
From 1984 to 1995, he works in Madrid, Spain, in private enterprise Local Area Networks, S.A., as an Analyst / Programmer in several projects for the Institute of Foreign Trade (ICEX), for public company Telefónica Investigación y Desarrollo (TID), for the Spanish Industrial Credit Bank (BCI) and for the Spanish Army in the context of project RADITE (Automatic Digital Network Integrated Tactical Army). He works as well as Project Manager for flight company IBERIA in a message switching application for international connections with British Airways and Air France, among others. He also serves as a System Analyst - Project Manager in various companies in Andersen Consulting Group for a maintenance system called SIMOC (Integral On-Condition Maintenance System) for Spanish Air Force combat aircraft EF-18. He ends working at Madrid as a freelance for ALCATEL in a Research and Development project on Monitoring System for Aircraft Guidance for Domestic Airports, under the technical supervision of the National Institute of Aerospace Technology (INTA) and the control of the Spanish Ministry of Transport, National Airports and Air Navigation (AENA).
In 1995 he starts teaching at the University of Castilla-La Mancha. He is the head of the n&aIS (Artificial and Natural Interaction Systems) team, belonging to the LoUISE (Laboratory on User Interfaces and Software Engineering) research laboratory at the Computer Science Research Institute at Albacete (i3A) since 2001. Among his research interests are computer vision, pattern recognition, human-machine interaction and multi-agent systems.
He is an Associate Editor of the Pattern Recognition Letters international journal.

position.title: Managing Editor
position.summary:
IJACSA's mission is to provide an outlet for quality research to be publicised and published to a global audience. It aims freely to promote universal access with equal opportunities for international scientific community; to scientific knowledge, and the creation, and dissemination of scientific and technical information
In sync with the Journal's vision “ to be a globally respected publication that provides best-of breed Research Papers and Discussions, leveraging technology, delivered by best-in-class people” we have drawn the best of talent from Industries and Institutions across the globe to ensure that we retain high standards.
At IJACSA, we stand strong because we know that global challenges make way for new innovations, new ways and new talent.
IJACSA encourages submissions of papers addressing theoretical and practical implementations in information and systems applications. It also focusses on areas such as Artificial Intelligence, Networking, Multimedia Tools, Virtual Reality and Computational Intelligence to name a few.
IJACSA solicits papers in domains that have not been represented much in the past at the conference, such as database security/privacy, usability aspects, operating systems, and Self Learning Capability algorithms.
Papers that introduce and address unique algorithms and application challenges or present thought-provoking ideas are welcome.

position.title: Postdoc
position.summary: NUIG Partner representative within the EU FP7 Digital.Me Project: Integrated Userware for the Intelligent, Intuitive, and Trust-Enhancing Management of the User's Personal Information Sphere in Digital and Social Environments

position.title: Researcher
position.summary:
Throughout the course of my Ph.D. I have fulfilled the position of a researcher at this international institute. Experiences gained include working within different international teams (involving both academia and enterprise) in a number of projects, supervising students, leading project task forces and writing successful project proposals, as well as representing the institute in international events on many occasions.
In particular, while in DERI I have contributed to the following projects:
Nepomuk: The Social Semantic Desktop (2006-2008) This projects brought together researchers and industrial software developers to develop a comprehensive solution for extending the personal desktop into a collaboration environment which supports both the personal information management and the sharing and exchange across social and organisational relations. Within this project, I was entrusted to lead the Ontologies Task Force, which was responsible for the knowledge modelling aspect of the architecture.
Digital Me: Userware for the Semantic Personal Sphere (2010-present) This project aims at the integration and management of all personal data within a user’s personal sphere via a single user-controlled point of access: the digital.me userware. Disclosable personal information will be shared with peers and services via digital faces, i.e. automatically generated context-dependant views of user’s information, subject to privacy settings. Within this project, I lead the work package responsible for the lifting , representation and processing of personal data.

position.title: FRESNEL Research Fellow
position.summary: The FRESNEL project is concerned with the development and deployment of a federated wireless sensor network (WSN) across the University of Cambridge campus. My role in the project is to research and design methods and technologies to preserve the privacy of personal data gathered by the network, whilst still allowing the network to provide useful statistical information.

position.title: Postdoctoral Researcher
position.summary: My major role at Siegen was to manage and write an EU Framework Programme 7 Integrating Project (IP) proposal, involving 16 universities and industrial partners, to investigate the security and privacy issues of cloud computing. In my time in Siegen I also conducted research into security, privacy-enhancing technologies and anonymous communications.

position.title: PhD Student
position.summary: My PhD in the computer science department at the University of York focused on the classification and analysis of fundamental strategies for anonymous communications.

position.title: Undergraduate Student
position.summary:
I studied Computer Science for four years, receiving an MComp masters' degree. The course was relatively engineering-based, although I focused more on the theoretical courses with a particular interest in the pi-calculus.
My third-year undergraduate research project simulated social insect communities, looking at ant foraging strategies as well as implementing a CORBA-based mobile agent system modelled on bee behaviour.
My fourth-year individual research project involved modelling the TLS protocol in the SPI calculus, a version of the pi-calculus with cryptographic primitives added.
